text: After the Golden Age, the Islamic world had a geographically wide but politically more fragmented structure. In this period, states emerging in different regions undertook roles such as ensuring order in their circles, developing culture, strengthening urbanization, and keeping trade alive. This period, which lasted from the 14th century to the end of the 19th century, is an era when the regional diversification of Islamic civilization became distinct.
The Ottomans established a state structure providing stability for a long time in a wide geography extending from the Balkans to the Middle East, from North Africa to the Caucasus.
The Ottoman administration hosted different religious, ethnic, and cultural communities under the same administrative roof. This structure played an important role in preserving a long-term order.

Madrasas, libraries, and foundation institutions formed the basis of education and social life. These institutions provided education in fields such as law, mathematics, and medicine as well as religious sciences.

Architecture developing in Istanbul, Bursa, Edirne, and many other cities revealed important examples reflecting the artistic understanding of the period. Mosques, complexes, and social structures were structures regulating city life.
The Ottomans became one of the main actors protecting the political order in the western region of the Islamic geography in this period.
The Safavids established a strong state structure based in Iran. They became a power influencing the political and cultural direction of the region for a long time.
In the Safavid period, Isfahan especially became a center where art and architecture developed. Squares, palaces, and bridges highlight the aesthetic understanding of the period.
Regulating trade routes, strengthening regional administration, and supporting urbanization were among the basic works of the Safavid administration.
The Safavids were an important part of the political balance in the eastern region of the Islamic world.
The Timurids were effective in Central Asia and the geography of Iran. Although their political dominance was limited in time, their cultural effects were long-lasting.

content.section: a) Protection of Science and Art
text: Timurid palaces supported studies in mathematics, astronomy, and history. Samarkand and Herat became some of the most important science and art centers of the period.
Timurid architecture is known for its domes, tiles, and wide courtyards. This style influenced many regions in the following centuries.
The Mughals established a strong state in the geography of India and deeply affected the cultural structure of the region.

Many works recognized worldwide, such as the Taj Mahal, were built during the Mughal period. The architecture of these structures consists of a synthesis of Central Asian, Persian, and Indian cultures.
The Mughals tried to unite different communities in the region within the same administrative system. This multicultural structure contributed to the social diversity of the region.

content.section: 5. Regional Structures in North Africa, Arabia, and Central Asia
text: It is important to emphasize that late Islamic history did not consist only of great empires. In the same period:
-Local dynasties in North Africa,
-Various Turkic khanates in Central Asia,
-Regional administrations in the Arabian Peninsula
undertook the duties of ensuring stability in their regions and protecting social order.
These structures were administrations shaped according to their own internal dynamics but were part of the same civilization area.
Late period Islamic states have an important place in history as political organizations that:
-Spread to different geographies,
-Formed multicultural structures,
-Left permanent works in the fields of science, art, architecture, and administration,
-And provided regional stability.

This period shows that Islamic civilization evolved from a single-centered structure to a model with a multi-centered and wide cultural diversity. This diversity allowed the civilization to be enriched and different regions to reveal their own unique contributions.
